sen.j: 芸道（げいどう）は、芸能・技芸を日本独自のかたちで体系化したもののことを指す。
sen.e: Geido is a name for performing arts and handicrafts, which are systematized by Japanese unique way.
Geido is a name for performing arts and handicrafts, which are systematized by Japanese unique way.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: Geido refers to the performance of arts and handicrafts in a systematized way that is uniquely Japanese.
sen.cmt: NCコメントを受けて，翻訳し直しました。

sen.j: 通常は、各種の武芸である日本武術、江戸期の公家家職に由来する有職故実・礼式、そのほか能楽、歌舞伎、人形浄瑠璃などの芸能、邦楽、茶道、華道、香道、書道、盆庭などをはじめとして、伝統工芸的な手工業、古典園芸など、ひろく技術を伝承する分野においてこうした観念が見られる。
sen.e: Normally, this idea can be seen in Japanese martial art and Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette), or reishiki which are originated in Court nobles in Edo period, and also can be seen in performing arts such as Nogaku, Kabuki, and Ningyo Joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater), and in fields where skills are broadly succeeded, starting with Hogaku (traditional Japanese music), Sado (tea ceremony), Kado (flower arrangement), Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony), Shodo (calligraphy), and Bontei (tray garden), which are traditional handicrafts and gardening.

Normally, this idea can be seen in Japanese martial art and Yusoku kojitsu (court and samurai rules of ceremony and etiquette), or reishiki which are originated in Court nobles in Edo period, and also can be seen in performing arts such as Nogaku, Kabuki, and Ningyo Joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater), and in fields where skills are broadly succeeded, starting with Hogaku (traditional Japanese music), Sado (tea ceremony), Kado (flower arrangement), Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony), Shodo (calligraphy), and Bontei (tray garden), which are traditional handicrafts and gardening.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: This concept can normally be seen in the various Nihon bujutsu (Japanese martial arts) and the Yusoku kojitsu (traditional protocol of the imperial court and samurai families) or reishiki (etiquette) that are derived from the practices and manners observed by court nobles in the Edo period; it can also be seen in fields where skills are passed down from one generation to the next, ranging from performing arts such as Nohgaku, Kabuki, and Ningyo Joruri (traditional Japanese puppet theater), Hogaku (traditional Japanese music), Sado (tea ceremony), Kado (flower arrangement), Kodo (traditional incense-smelling ceremony), Shodo (calligraphy), Bontei (tray garden) to traditional handicrafts and classic gardening.
sen.cmt: NCコメントを受けて，翻訳し直しました。

sen.j: 元来「道」という言葉は日本語において「体系」という意味をも持ち、王朝時代から管弦のことを「糸竹の道」と表現するなどの用例があることをみてもわかるように、芸について「みち」もしくは「道」で表現される内容は最初は単純に「芸の体系」というほどの意味であったと思われる。
sen.e: Originally, the word 'do' (or 'michi') means 'system' in Japanese, and like seen in example of usage of the word where wind and string instruments were called 'Itotake no michi' in Dynastic period, it can be thought that at first, it simply meant 'system of art' when 'michi' or 'do' was used to express art.

Originally, the word 'do' (or 'michi') meant 'system' in Japanese and, as shown by the example in which wind and string instruments were referred to as 'Itotake no michi' during the Dynastic period, it is thought that 'michi' or 'do' first meant simply 'system of art' when used in relation to the arts.
sen.cmt: Poor translation. It did not accurately reflect the source text.Completely retranslated.
sen.e: Originally, the word 'do' (or 'michi') meant 'system' in Japanese and, as shown by the example in which wind and string instruments have been referred to as 'Itotake no michi' since the Dynastic period, it is thought that 'michi' or 'do' first meant simply 'system of art' when used in relation to the arts.
sen.cmt: have been referred to as ～since ～ としました。

sen.j: これが中世期から近世期にかけて、さまざまな芸が体系化され伝授の形式を整えてゆくにつれて、単に芸能、技芸の体系というにとどまらず、それをめぐる思想や哲学的背景、さらに修行や日常生活の場においてこうした形而上的な問題をいかに生かし、みずからの芸を高めてゆくかという問題が含められてゆくようになって成立したのが、芸道という観念である。
sen.e: When various arts became systematized in Medieval Period through early-modern times, it started to have more meanings, not just simply meaning system, but also including ideas and philosophical backgrounds of arts, and problems that how these metaphysical problems can be used in ascetic practices and daily life to heighten one's own art, and the idea of Geigo was established.

When various arts became systematized from the middle ages to the early modern period, it started to take on more meanings, not simply meaning system but also including ideas and philosophical backgrounds of arts, and the issue of how these metaphysical problems could be used in ascetic practice and daily life to heighten one's own art, leading to the establishment of the concept of geido.
sen.cmt: Poor translation. Inappropriate terminology, incorrect spelling of key term, poor phrasing.Rewritten to read naturally.
sen.e: When various arts became systematized from the middle ages to the early modern period, it started to take on more meanings, not simply meaning system of performing arts and techniques, but also including ideas and philosophical backgrounds of arts, and the issue of how these metaphysical problems could be used in ascetic practice and daily life to heighten one's own art, leading to the establishment of the concept of geido.
sen.cmt: 芸能、技芸 を追加しました。

sen.j: その成立に関しては中世期に盛んになった秘伝説と伝授思想の確立と、師系を重んじる禅の発想が大きな影響を与えたと見るのが通説である。
sen.e: It is common to see that as for the establishment of Geido, the establishment of ideas about succeeding in secrets, which became popular in Medieval Period, and ideas of Zen, which regards mentor highly, gave great influence.

It is common to see that as for the establishment of Geido, the establishment of ideas about succeeding in secrets, which became popular in Medieval Period, and ideas of Zen, which regards mentor highly, gave great influence.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The establishment of Geido is commonly thought to have been greatly influenced by the popularization of esoteric theories and initiation ideas in medieval times, as well as the development of Zen beliefs, according to which mentors are highly regarded.
sen.cmt: NCコメントを受けて，翻訳し直しました。

sen.j: 芸能、技芸を技術的な問題としてのみ捉えることをせず、しばしば実生活と芸の世界を混同させて、常住坐臥が芸を高めるための契機であり、修行であると考え、しかのみならず当人の倫理性、道徳性がそのまま芸にあらわれるがゆえに、芸の向上は同時に人格の向上でなければならない、とするところに芸道の特徴がある。
sen.e: The main characteristic of Geido is the idea that performing arts and handicrafts are not just the problem of skills, but the daily lives and arts are mixed up, and at all times, there are chances to heighten one's art and ascetic practices are conducted, and not only that, since one's ethic and morality show up directly on arts, heightening of one's art should be the heightening of one's personality.

The main characteristic of Geido is the idea that performing arts and handicrafts are not just the problem of skills, but the daily lives and arts are mixed up, and at all times, there are chances to heighten one's art and ascetic practices are conducted, and not only that, since one's ethic and morality show up directly on arts, heightening of one's art should be the heightening of one's personality.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: The main characteristic of Geido is the idea that the heightening of one's art should be simultaneously accompanied by a heightening of one's personality because one's ethics and morality are directly revealed in one's art; this is derived from the idea that rather than regarding the performance of arts and techniques as merely a matter of skill, we should merge our everyday lives and the world of art, which is an opportunity to heighten our art and is itself a form of training.
sen.cmt: NCコメントを受けて，翻訳し直しました。

sen.j: また芸の系統的な伝承を重んじ、先人をうやまうことが厚く、特に直接の師弟関係を大切にするなど、水平方向的なひろがりよりも垂直方向的なつらなりを優先する。
sen.e: Also, it regards systematic succession highly, respect predecessors highly, and especially consider direct teacher-disciple relationship important, giving priority to vertical relations rather than horizontal relations.

It also values the systematic transmission of arts, and prioritizes vertical relationships over horizontal relationships with elements such as great respect for one's predecessors and a particular importance on the direct teacher-disciple relationship.
sen.cmt: Rewritten to read more professionally.
sen.e: It also values the systematic transmission of arts, and prioritizes vertical relationships over horizontal relationships with elements such as great respect for one's predecessors and a particular importance on the direct teacher-disciple relationship.
sen.cmt: 修正なし

sen.j: こうした考えかたは、日本独自の芸という観念の確立、心境や境地を特に重視する芸術観の尊重、芸系のたしかな伝承、芸が芸にとどまらず思索性を持つことによる内容の深化など、さまざまな効果をもたらしたが、一方で芸の世界における事大主義、神秘主義、普遍性の否定、通に代表される特殊な閉鎖性を生むことにもなった。
sen.e: This way of thinking, on one hand, made various effects such as establishment of Japanese own idea of arts, respect for view of arts giving importance to a state of mind and mental state, certain succession of arts, and deepening of arts not only by its skills but also by meditation, but on the other hand, gave birth to this special exclusiveness, such as worship of powerful, mysticism, denial of universality, and tsu (being expert at certain arts).

This way of thinking, on one hand, made various effects such as establishment of Japanese own idea of arts, respect for view of arts giving importance to a state of mind and mental state, certain succession of arts, and deepening of arts not only by its skills but also by meditation, but on the other hand, gave birth to this special exclusiveness, such as worship of powerful, mysticism, denial of universality, and tsu (being expert at certain arts).
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: On the one hand, this way of thinking had various positive effects such as the establishment of ideas regarding Gei that are peculiar to Japan, respect for artistic views that place special importance on one's feelings and mental state, the correct passing on of arts knowledge from one generation to the next, and the deepening of arts not only through acquisition of its skills but also by speculation; on the other hand, it had a number of negative effects, such as worship of the powerful in the world of arts, mysticism, denial of universality, and development of a uniquely closed nature as represented by tsu (experts at certain arts).
sen.cmt: NCコメントを受けて，翻訳し直しました。

sen.j: 外国人にはこうした日本固有の芸道観念が興味深くうつるらしく、ドイツ人の哲学者オイゲン・ヘリゲルが、東北大学に在任中、洋弓（アーチェリー）とは違った日本の弓道の修業の仕方に感銘を受けて『弓と禅』をあらわしたのを嚆矢として、欧米世界にさまざまに紹介されている。
sen.e: This idea of Geido, which is peculiar to Japan, seems to interest foreigners, and like when German philosopher Eugen Herrigel wrote "Zen in the Art of Archery" when he was deeply impressed by the way of practicing Kyudo (archery) in Japan, different from archery, when he was in Tohoku University, it is introduced in various ways to the Western World.

This idea of Geido, which is peculiar to Japan, seems to interest foreigners, and like when German philosopher Eugen Herrigel wrote "Zen in the Art of Archery" when he was deeply impressed by the way of practicing Kyudo (archery) in Japan, different from archery, when he was in Tohoku University, it is introduced in various ways to the Western World.
sen.cmt: 修正なし
sen.e: This idea of Geido, which is peculiar to Japan, seems to interest foreigners, such that when German philosopher Eugen Herrigel was at Tohoku University, for example, he was so impressed by how different the practice of Kyudo (Japanese archery) was from that of western-style archery that he wrote "Zen in the Art of Archery," a book that has been introduced to the Western World through various means.
sen.cmt: NCコメントを受けて，翻訳し直しました。

sen.j: 芸道という言葉自体は、明治に「柔道」なる新語が登場したのを受けて、剣道、華道、茶道といった造語が相次ぎ、これを総称するために生れたものである。
sen.e: In Meiji period, when the word 'Judo' was born, other words such as Kendo, Kado, and Sado were made, and to call these words as a whole, the word Geido was born.
The word 'geido' was coined as a general term for words such a as 'kendo,' 'kado' and 'sado' which came into use following the creation of the word 'judo.'
